posts._title: Oumarou Ganda – Le wazzou polygame AKA The Polygamous Wazzou (1971)
posts.title: Le wazzou polygame
posts.excerpt: A practicing Muslim takes title of al-Hajj on his return from Mecca. However, this doesn’t stop him from lusting after the young Satou, promised to Garba. Furious, Garba feels he has no choice but to leave the village for the town. Yet a more serious tragedy is afoot.

posts._title: Andrzej Wajda – Panny z Wilka AKA Young Girls Of Wilko [+Extras] (1979)
posts.title: Panny z Wilka
posts.excerpt: Quote:Set in the late ’20s. A thirtyish young man, who heads a small factory, faints at the funeral of a close friend. He decides to go home to his aunt and uncle for a while, but gets involved with a family of five women who had been in love with him at one time though …

posts.title: Senso
posts.excerpt: Quote:This lush, Technicolor tragic romance from Luchino Visconti stars Alida Valli as a nineteenth-century Italian countess who, during the Austrian occupation of her country, puts her marriage and political principles on the line by engaging in a torrid affair with a dashing Austrian lieutenant, played by Farley Granger. Gilded with ornate costumes and sets and …

posts._title: Toshiaki Toyoda – Monsutâzu kurabu AKA Monsters Club (2011)
posts.title: Monsutâzu kurabu
posts.excerpt: Quote:Having abandoned modern civilization, Ryoichi lives an isolated, self-sufficient life on a snow-covered mountain and sends mail bombs to the CEOs of corporations and TV networks. One day, he encounters a mysterious creature in the forest. That night, his older brother, who had committed suicide, appears before him at his cabin. The apparition takes Ryoichi …

posts.title: No Land’s Song
posts.excerpt: Quote:In Iran, since the 1979 Islamic revolution, women are no longer allowed to sing in public as soloists – at least in front of men. Defying censorship and taboos, the young composer Sara Najafi is determined to organize an official concert for solo female singers. In order to support their fight, Sara and her friends …

posts.title: Edward II
posts.excerpt: Words from Ian McKellenWhen Toby Robertson, artistic director of Prospect Theatre, decided to revive our Richard II, he thought to accompany it with his own production of Edward II, a play he had previously directed with Derek Jacobi and other Cambridge undergraduates in 1957. posts._title: Juan Bustillo Oro & Fernando de Fuentes – El compadre Mendoza AKA Godfather Mendoza (1934)
posts.title: El compadre Mendoza
posts.excerpt: Synopsis:During Mexican Revolution, Rosalio Mendoza (Del Diestro) survives by making and winning favors from both factions, the governmental forces and Zapata’s Army. His hacienda welcomes everybody, and Mendoza is considered a good friend of his guests. Eventually, the situation becomes unsustainable and he has to take sides. Betrayal and deception overcome and Mendoza’s dark side …
posts.director: Juan Bustillo Oro & Fernando de Fuentes

posts.title: Magallanes
posts.excerpt: Quote:“Del Solar turns the screws on the audience expertly, but the thriller elements never distract from the moral crisis of a man — and a country — whose decades-old mistakes cling to him like a tattoo”—Variety Taxi driver Magallanes (Damián Alcázar) struggles to get by, and spends his spare time with his former military superior, …

posts.title: Kyôshû
posts.excerpt: This ATG film is a family drama set in 1953 in a small rural town in Tosa, Kochi. This was the first directorial effort by Takehiro Nakajima, a novelist whose work was adapted into Preparation for the Festival by Kazuo Kuroki.

posts.title: Sakay
posts.excerpt: Quote:“Filipinas, farewell! Long live the Republic and may our independence be born in the future!” Those were Macario Sakay’s last words before he was executed by hanging on September 13, 1907 for treason. His real crime was patriotism, breaking rank with the leaders who sold out the Philippine Revolution to the United States and waging …
